Name: ReqID
Notes: Requirements Identifier

Name: Environment
Notes: The surrounding conditions, context, and external influences that affect entities, agents, or systems

Name: Events
Notes:
Occurrences or happenings that involve changes in substances or their properties. They are often seen as the dynamic aspect of reality.  
  • Temporal Events: Events that occur within time, such as a leaf falling from a tree.
  • Timeless Events: Philosophically debated, these refer to occurrences that are outside the usual flow of time.

e.g.
Correctness, completeness, consistency, etc.

Name: Creation Viewpoint : Interactions
Notes: Creation Viewpoint : Interactions

Name: Adaptation Viewpoint : System context
Notes: Adaptation Viewpoint : System context

Name: Creation Viewpoint : Interactions
Notes: Creation Viewpoint : Interactions

Name: Mental models
Notes: Cognitive frameworks or representations that aid in understand and interpretting the world, predicting outcomes, and guiding behavior.

Name: Space and Time
Notes:
Space and time are the frameworks within which physical reality is structured.  
  • Space: The three-dimensional continuum in which objects are located and interact.
  • Time: The linear progression of events from the past, through the present, to the future. Some metaphysical perspectives consider time to be another dimension, much like space.

Name: Causality
Notes:
Causality is the principle that events occur as a result of other events or states of affairs. It establishes a relationship between cause and effect.  
  • Efficient Causes: Causes that bring something into existence or effect a change.
  • Final Causes: The purpose or end for which something is done, a concept especially highlighted in Aristotelian philosophy.

Name: Universals and Particulars
Notes: a classical metaphysical distinction about the nature of properties and entities

Name: Possibility and Necessity
Notes:
These concepts deal with the nature of existence and non-existence.  
  • Possible Worlds: Hypothetical realities that represent different ways things could have been.
  • Necessary Existence: Entities that must exist in any possible world, such as mathematical truths or logical laws.

Name: Mind and Consciousness
Notes:
This component explores the nature of the mind and its relationship to reality.  
  • Dualism: The view that mind and matter are distinct substances.
  • Monism: The belief that only one kind of substance exists, with variations like materialism (only matter exists) and idealism (only mind exists).

Name: Ontology
Notes:
The study of being and existence that seek to categorize and understand the nature of entities and their modes of existence.  
  • Realism: The belief that entities exist independently of perception.
  • Nominalism: The view that universals are mere names without inherent reality.

Name: Metaphysical Grounding
Notes:
This concept involves the basis upon which reality is constructed.  
  • Fundamental Entities: The basic building blocks of reality that everything else depends on.
  • Grounding Relations: The hierarchical structure that explains how higher-level phenomena arise from more fundamental ones.

Context
Notes: the interpretive framework  and corresponding knowledge, experience, and perspective that give meaning to facts, actions, or ideas and promotes understanding of why something matters, how it fits into a bigger picture, or what it implies.

Name: Information
Notes: Data that has been processed and organized in a way that is meaningful for use in the form of facts, figures, and narratives.

Name: Material
Notes: Any substace or mixture of substances that has physical properties and is used for making things.

Name: Evidence
Notes: Anything presented in support of an assertion, as described here.

Name: Arguments
Notes: Arguments deal with whether claims are true or not, providing reasons to support that claim and implying that the premises make it reasonable to accept the conclusion. In contrast, an explanation describes the mechanism by which something happens, providing causal theories for why something could happen. Explanations may themselves be true or not (i.e. explain adequately why something happens), but they cannot be used as evidence to believe a claim – they make it plausible, but not certain.

Name: Claims
Notes: An idea that someone is trying to convince someone else is true, and which is debatable.

Name: Matter
Notes: The general term for anything that has mass and occupies space

Name: Liquid
Notes: Has a definite volume but takes the shape of its container. Particles are less tightly packed than in solids. Examples: Water, oil

Name: Solid
Notes: Has a definite shape and volume. Particles are tightly packed. Examples: Ice, iron

Name: Gas
Notes: Has no definite shape or volume. Particles are spread out and move freely. Examples: Oxygen, nitrogen

Name: Plasma
Notes: Ionized gas with free electrons. High-energy state found in stars, neon signs. Examples: Sun, lightning.

Name: Artifacts
Notes:
• Cultural Items: Art, literature, music.
  • Historical Artifacts: Ancient tools, manuscripts, relics.
  • Production artifacts: Plans, Designs, Reports, Data
SwiftSure.Pro Version 2025-1

Name: Facts
Notes: Statements that can be proven true or false, are consistent with objective reality, and are specific, verifiable, and represent a concrete piece of information; typically derived from observations, evidence, experiments, and reliable sources.

Name: Reality
Notes: The aggregation of all that is real or existent, grounded in the physical universe, and the laws that govern it. The state of things as they actually are, independent of perception, beliefs, or theories, whether observable or beyond human comprehension.

Name: Perceptions
Notes: the organization, identification, and interpretation of sensory information in order to represent and understand the presented information, or the environment, as described here
Particular instances of things with extensions in space and time
Idealized, holistic universals, the abstract classes into which we mentally organize reality

Name: Aggregations
Notes:
Aggregation represents a "whole-part" relationship where the part can exist independently of the whole. It's often referred to as a "weak" relationship.

Represented by solid line with hollow diamond at owner end

Name: Compositions
Notes:
Represents a "whole-part" relationship where the part cannot exist independently of the whole. It's often referred to as a "strong" relationship.

Represented by solid line with filled diamond at owner end
Substances can survive changes to their part instances in a way that mere aggregations of parts cannot

Name: Causal chains
Notes: A sequence of events where the results of each activity depend upon prior results of earlier activities and influence subsequent ones. This concept is fundamental to understanding how one action or event can lead to a series of consequences.
Items of definition or reference
While bundles of properties come and go, a particular thing is a succession of such bundles which have a continuity running throughout
The recombinations that are merely possible have no concrete existence.
Where do absences, lacks, edges, emptinesses, limits, holes, zeros, missings, voids, and endings fit?

Name: Objects
Notes: Particular instances of things with extensions in space and time

Name: Properties
Notes: Inherent behavior-oriented qualities possessed by entities that define their nature.

Name: Relationships
Notes: Connections between entities that define how they interact and relate to each other.

Name: Concepts
Notes: Abstract general notions or mental representations of categories or objects

Name: Data
Notes: Raw information collected through observations, measurements, or research.

Name: Entities
Notes: items of definition or reference that claim independent existence and a distinctive identify

Name: Things
Notes: Idealized, holistic classes that we mentally organize reality into to communicate core properties that justify treating them together as one conceptualization
whether used as a subject or as an object, existing actually or potentially, and conceptualized concretely or abstractly, as described here.
whether used as a subject or as an object, existing actually or potentially, and conceptualized concretely or abstractly, as described here.

Name: Compounds
Notes: Two or more elements chemically bonded. Examples: Water (H₂O), carbon dioxide (CO₂)

Name: Mixtures
Notes: Combinations of two or more substances physically blended but not chemically bonded

Name: Homogeneous Mixtures
Notes: Uniform composition. Examples: Saltwater, air

Name: Heterogeneous Mixtures
Notes: Non-uniform composition. Examples: Salad, sand and iron filings

Name: Natural objects
Notes:
• Living Organisms: Animals, plants, fungi, microorganisms.
  • Non-living Elements: Rocks, minerals, water, air.

Name: Man-made objects
Notes:
• Technology: Systems, equipment, vehicles, networks
  • Structures: Buildings, bridges, roads, infrastructure
  • Agricultural products
  • Energy stores
  • Stores of value

Name: Conceptual Entities
Notes:
• Ideas: Theories, beliefs, plans
  • Concepts: Freedom, justice, beauty

Name: Abstract things
Notes:
• Mathematical Entities: Numbers, shapes, equations
  • Linguistic entities: Words, sentences, languages

Name: Phenomena
Notes: Any observable event, occurrence, or process that can be studied or experienced.

Name: Substances
Notes: Specific forms of matter with uniform properties which is often considered the primary constituent of reality.

Name: Probe opportunities
Notes: Gathering data through experiments, observations, or surveys

Name: Verification and validation
Notes: Checking the accuracy and consistency of the data

Name: Analysis
Notes: Interpreting data through statistical methods or analytical models

Name: Peer reviews
Notes: Soliciting and dispositioning feedback from experts re the data and methods

Name: Findings
Notes: Sharing findings with the broader community through journals, networks, reports, and presentations

Name: Acceptance by stakeholders
Notes: The target community accepts the data as factual and relevant
Concrete
Abstract
Particulars

Name: Truth
Notes: Statements, propositions, and beliefs that align with facts or reality. A statement is true if it accurately reflects the state of affairs it describes. Truth is the foundational concept that underpins verifiable facts, ensuring consistency, objectivity, and coherence in our understanding of reality.

Name: Agents
Notes: Autonomous entities that can perceive their environment, make decisions, and perform actions to achieve specific goals.
Universals

Name: Attributes
Notes: Features that provide information about an entity and describe specific details to identify or classify it

Name: Associations
Notes:
Represents a structural relationship between elements, where one element is connected to another.

Depicted by solid line connecting elements

Name: Correspondence
Notes: Truth corresponds to reality or facts. A statement is true if it accurately represents the state of affairs in the real world.

Name: Consistency
Notes: Truth is consistent and coherent with other established truths. It does not contradict other known facts or truths.

Name: Objectivity
Notes: Truth is objective and independent of individual beliefs or perceptions. It remains true regardless of subjective opinions.

Name: Universality
Notes: Truth is universal and applies to all individuals and contexts. It is not limited to specific cultures, times, or places.

Name: Verifiability
Notes: Truth can be verified or tested through evidence, observation, or experimentation. It can be demonstrated to be true.

Name: Immutability
Notes: Truth is unchanging and remains constant over time. Once established, it does not alter.

Name: Explanatory power
Notes: Truth provides explanations for phenomena and enhances understanding. It offers insights into the workings of the world

Name: Pragmatism
Notes: Truth is practical and has utility. It can be applied to solve problems and achieve desired outcomes.

Name: Dependency
Notes:
Indicates that one element depends on another. If the dependent element changes, it may impact the element that depends on it.

Represented by dashed line with open arrowhead pointing to dependent element

Name: Generalization
Notes:
Shows an inheritance relationship, where a more specific element (child) inherits the properties and behaviors of a more general element (parent).

Represented by solid line with hollow triangle pointing to parent element

Name: Realization
Notes:
Indicates that one element (usually an interface or requirement) is implemented or satisfied by another element.

Represented by dashed line with hollow triangle pointing to realized element

Name: Containment
Notes:
Specifies that one element is contained within another, often used to represent hierarchical structures.

Depicted in package diagrams by nesting them

Name: Refinement
Notes:
Links an abstract element to a more concrete element that refines or implements it.

Represented using same convention as dependency with label <<refine>>

Name: Trace
Notes: Establishes a traceability relationship between elements, indicating that one element is related to another in some way, often used for requirements traceability.

Assertions of "True" and "False" stand only for a general dimension of being: one in which assertions can be limited within defined circumstances, for a particular audience, given prescribed intentions and asumptions, and towards achievement of specific purposes.

Name: Knowledge
Notes: Knowledge is the understanding and awareness of justified true beliefs gained through experience, education, and the application of information. It involves cognitive processing, synthesis, and interpretation to leverage connections between different pieces of information and their meaning.

Name: Wisdom
Notes: The highest level of cognitive processing involves the ability to make sound judgments and decisions based on deep understanding and experience.

Name: Intentions
Notes: The aims, plans, or purposes that drive an agent to act in a certain way, through  conscious decisions to perform specific actions to achieve desired outcomes.
Some properties emerge at a particular higher level of reality and nothing like them is found at the level of their parts.
Intrinsic: Properties inherent to an object, such as mass, shape, and color. Extrinsic: Properties dependent on the object's relationship to other things, such as location or ownership.

Universals: Properties or qualities that multiple entities can have in common, such as redness or beauty. Particulars: Individual entities that possess unique properties, like a specific apple or a particular painting.

Physical Substance: Refers to physical matter, the stuff that makes up the tangible world, often considered the primary constituent of reality. It refers to that which exists independently and is the bearer of properties or attributes. Immaterial Substance: Refers to non-physical entities. Examples include the mind or soul, which some philosophies argue are distinct from the body.

The ability to grasp the meaning of information, texts, or concepts by decoding and interpreting data to recognize what is being communicated literally without delving into implications or connections
Connecting new information with context including existing knowledge to make sense and gain insight of its broader implications, significance, and relationships.

Name: Cognition
Notes: Cognitive processes provide the foundation for interpreting and responding to the world, ultimately guiding behavior.
Consider depracating this
Gather information using senses or tools
Drawing upon current and historical information to anticipate future trends and implications
Putting information into action that will achieve meaningful progress towards goals

Name: Inference
Notes: The act of deducing new information based on what is already known

Name: Nesting
Notes:
Depicts a representation of containment or composition, used to show hierarchical relationships in diagrams without defining ownership and namespace

Represented by a solid line with a cross-hatched circle on the parent end

Name: Ideas
Notes: Specific instances of thinking that manifest as thoughts, plans, or opinions

Name: Operations
Notes: Capabilities that can be performed by and are provided by a class of entities

Name: Inherent and Fundamental beliefs
Notes:
• Existential: revolve around questions of existence, purpose, and the nature of reality. Examples include beliefs about life after death, the existence of a higher power, or the meaning of life.
  • Epistemological: concern the nature and scope of knowledge and understanding. They include concepts like skepticism, empiricism, and rationalism, which dictate how individuals perceive and acquire knowledge.

Name: Normative and Ethical
Notes:
• Moral Principles: ideas about what is right and wrong, often influenced by cultural, religious, or philosophical frameworks. Examples include utilitarianism, deontology, and virtue ethics.
  • Justice and Fairness: deal with the principles of equality, rights, and fairness in human interactions. They shape beliefs about law, governance, and social justice.

Name: Aesthetic and Creative
Notes:
• Artistic Expression: involve concepts of beauty, creativity, and artistic value. They influence our appreciation of art, literature, music, and other forms of creative expression.
  • Cultural Norms: shared ideas within a community about what is considered acceptable or valuable in terms of customs, traditions, and cultural practices.

Name: Pragmatic and Functional
Notes:
• Scientific and Technological: grounded in empirical evidence and rational thought. They encompass scientific theories, technological advancements, and practical applications of knowledge.
  • Economic and Political: ideas about the organization and management of resources, power, and societal structures. They include economic theories, political ideologies, and governance models.

Name: Personal and Psychological
Notes:
• Identity and Self-concept: These ideas pertain to one's understanding of self and personal identity. They shape how individuals see themselves and their roles in the world.
  • Motivational and Aspirational: These concepts include goals, ambitions, and personal motivations. They drive behavior and decision-making processes.
